title: Remove Unneeded OSS_RN Special Path
body:
We should be able to remove this now that we moved bytecode caching out
of the Executor APIs

###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](http://wpcp.azurewebsites.net/CodeFlowProtocolProxy2.php?pullrequest=https://github.com/microsoft/react-native-windows/pull/3837)

title: Add GetFacebookReactInstance
body:
To get `facebook::react::Instance` from `uwp::Instance`

The reason not to do this directly in client application is, it requires the client application to include too many header files that are not designed to be included out side of ReactUWP, and it requires the client application to do too many configuration in its vcxproj file, which is not practical for consumers.

An `uwp::Instance` is needed for turbo module users for registering native module implementations.

###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](http://wpcp.azurewebsites.net/CodeFlowProtocolProxy2.php?pullrequest=https://github.com/microsoft/react-native-windows/pull/3782)

title: TextInput's onFocus and onBlur functions are not being executed
body:
### Environment

<!--
  Please fill in all the relevant fields by running these commands in terminal.
-->
1. `react-native -v`:
react-native-cli: 2.0.1
react-native: 0.60.6
2. `npm ls rnpm-plugin-windows`:
rnpm-plugin-windows@0.3.5
3. `npm ls react-native-windows`:
react-native-windows@0.60.0-vnext.91
4. `node -v`:
v10.15.0
5. `npm -v`:
6.13.1

Then, specify:

<!-- (What SDK version are you building for? Choose from 10.0.15063, 10.0.16299, 10.0.18362, etc. -->
- Target Platform Version(s): 10.0.18362.0

<!-- (What device(s) are you targeting? Choose any from Desktop, Xbox, Hololens) -->
- Target Device(s): Desktop

<!-- Which version of Visual Studio are you using? Specify Visual Studio 2017 or Visual Studio 2019 -->
- Visual Studio Version: 2017

<!-- Which build configuration are you running? Choose from Debug, DebugBundle, Release, ReleaseBundle -->
- Build Configuration: Debug

### Steps to Reproduce

<!--
  How would you describe your issue to someone who doesn’t know you or your project?
  Try to write a sequence of steps that anybody can repeat to see the issue.
  Be specific! If the bug cannot be reproduced, your issue may be closed.
-->

1. Create a TextInput in a project using React Native Windows
2. Supply an onFocus and onBlur function to the TextInput
3. Launch the app and focus or blur the TextInput
4. Observe that the code in the onFocus and onBlur provided to the TextInput is not executed

Example code:

```
import * as RN from "react-native";

render() {
    return (
          <RN.TextInput onFocus={this._onFocus} onBlur={this._onBlur} />
     );
}

_onFocus = (event: RN.NativeSyntheticEvent<RN.TextInputFocusEventData>) => {
     ...
}

_onBlur = (event: RN.NativeSyntheticEvent<RN.TextInputFocusEventData>) => {
     ...
}
```

### Expected Behavior

<!--
  How did you expect your project to behave?
  It’s fine if you’re not sure your understanding is correct.
  Just write down what you thought would happen.
-->

I expected the code in the _onFocus and _onBlur functions to be executed.

### Actual Behavior

<!--
  Did something go wrong?
  Is something broken, or not behaving as you expected?
  Describe this section in detail, and attach screenshots if possible.
  Don't just say "it doesn't work"!
-->

The code in the _onFocus and _onBlur functions was not executed.

title: Split lint tasks into separate build task to speed general build times
body:
Flow check in particular takes quite a while (although eslint isn't super quick either).  This makes the JS build task take longer than most of the builds need.

This change splits the build into a build task which does the required to run steps (file copies, ts -> JS transpile), and a lint task which runs eslint and flow-check.

Then I modified the CI loops so that only one of the builds runs the lint tasks, which reduces the build time of the other builds by > 90s.

###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](http://wpcp.azurewebsites.net/CodeFlowProtocolProxy2.php?pullrequest=https://github.com/microsoft/react-native-windows/pull/3841)

title: Update SampleModuleCpp library to show how to override module name
body:
The Name property in the current Cpp sample library is kind of misleading: people would think that is the way to override the native module name. 
Update the sample to show the correct way to override: through the second parameter of REACT_MODULE.

title: CLI template still builds ReactUWP
body: New CLI apps depend on Microsoft.ReactNative, which no longer needs to build ReactUWP. This dependency needs to be removed, and the docs need to be updated.

body:
Any http requests from a react native app which request progress updates will currently fail.

We currently use axios for http requests, and the library requests progress updates.
https://github.com/axios/axios/blob/503418718f669fcc674719fd862b355605d7b41f/lib/adapters/xhr.js

title: SectionList: Section header should be announced by narrator
body:
### Environment
Xbox Events Beta App

<!--
  Please fill in all the relevant fields by running these commands in terminal.
-->

1. `react-native -v`:
2. `npm ls rnpm-plugin-windows`: rnpm-plugin-windows@0.2.13 
3. `npm ls react-native-windows`: react-native-windows@0.60.0-vnext-headlessjs.49 
4. `node -v`: 10.15.0
5. `npm -v`: 6.4.1
6. `yarn --version`<!-- (if you use Yarn) -->:

Then, specify:

<!-- (What platform are you building for? Choose any from UWP, WPF) -->
- Target Platform: UWP

<!-- (What framework version are you building for? Choose from 10.0.14393, 10.0.10586, 10.0.10240, etc. (UWP), .NET 4.6.1, .NET 4.5, etc. (WPF) -->
- Target Platform Version(s):

<!-- (What device(s) are you targeting? Choose any from Desktop, Mobile (ARM), Mobile Emulator, Xbox, Hololens) -->
- Target Device(s): Xbox

<!-- Which operating system are you using? Specify macOS, Windows, or Linux, along with specific release versions -->
- Development Operating System: Xbox

<!-- Which version of Visual Studio are you using? Specify Visual Studio 2015 or Visual Studio 2017 -->
- Visual Studio Version: 

<!-- Which build configuration are you running? Choose from Debug, DebugBundle, Release, ReleaseBundle -->
- Build Configuration:

### Steps to Reproduce

<!--
  How would you describe your issue to someone who doesn’t know you or your project?
  Try to write a sequence of steps that anybody can repeat to see the issue.
  Be specific! If the bug cannot be reproduced, your issue may be closed.
-->
Xbox narrator cannot announce Section Header of the section list. Picture this, a visually impaired user navigates through a gaming event page. When the user navigates into a section filled with screenshots of a game, they will not be told they are currently in the "screenshot" section. Similarly, if an user is browsing through "Related games" on the bottom of a game product page, they will not be able to know the games they are hearing are "related games". This is a crucial feature for accessibility.

(Write your steps here:)
Note: 
1. Create a SectionList filled with buttons as items, and make sure to have section titles
2. Turn on system's narrator
3. Land focus on the first item of a section

### Expected Behavior
Narrator should announce the section header, so users know the section they are in.

<!--
  How did you expect your project to behave?
  It’s fine if you’re not sure your understanding is correct.
  Just write down what you thought would happen.
-->

(Write what you thought would happen.)

### Actual Behavior
Section header is not being announced. Only the text of the button was announced.

(Write what happened. Add screenshots!)

### Reproducible Demo

<!--
  Please share a project that reproduces the issue.
  There are two ways to do it:

    * Create a new app using https://snack.expo.io/ and try to reproduce the issue in it.
      This is useful if you roughly know where the problem is, or can’t share the real code.

    * Or, copy your app and remove things until you’re left with the minimal reproducible demo.
      This is useful for finding the root cause. You may then optionally create a Snack.

  This is a good guide to creating bug demos: https://stackoverflow.com/help/mcve
  Once you’re done, copy and paste the link to the Snack or a public GitHub repository below:
-->

(Paste the link to an example project and exact instructions to reproduce the issue.)

<!--
  What happens if you skip this step?

  Someone will read your bug report, and maybe will be able to help you,
  but it’s unlikely that it will get much attention from the team. Eventually,
  the issue will likely get closed in favor of issues that have reproducible demos.

  Please remember that:

    * Issues without reproducible demos have a very low priority.
    * The person fixing the bug would have to do that anyway. Please be respectful of their time.
    * You might figure out the issues yourself as you work on extracting it.

  Thanks for helping us help you!
-->

title: RNWCPP needs to support AcessibilityView Raw

milestone.title: MVP+ (vNext M5)
milestone.description:
After completing a MVP and moving vNext as the default template, this milestone covers work to fill out as much functionality as possible without requiring [WinUI 3](https://github.com/microsoft/microsoft-ui-xaml/blob/master/docs/roadmap.md#winui-3). Thus it will not achieve 100% core parity, but will increase completion.

Items of note:
- Match lean core (moving components out to extensions)
- Turbo Module support

body:
Currently, there is no way to set a component to Raw [AccessibilityView](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.automation.automationproperties.accessibilityview.aspx). As a result, specifying a label for CheckBox requires inserting a Text component, and Narrator is able to move focus to the Text.

- [ ] CheckBox
- [ ] Switch

Re-reading the [documentation about the accessible prop](https://facebook.github.io/react-native/docs/accessibility.html#accessible-ios-android), I wonder if setting accessible="true" on the Text's parent actually results in the correct behavior.

title: Document Accessibility Core Parity

milestone.title: MVP+ (vNext M5)
milestone.description:
After completing a MVP and moving vNext as the default template, this milestone covers work to fill out as much functionality as possible without requiring [WinUI 3](https://github.com/microsoft/microsoft-ui-xaml/blob/master/docs/roadmap.md#winui-3). Thus it will not achieve 100% core parity, but will increase completion.

Items of note:
- Match lean core (moving components out to extensions)
- Turbo Module support

body:
# Accessibility Core Parity

#### Legend:
- Yes - Implemented
- No - Intending to implement
- N/A - Not implementing
- FEVM - FrameworkElementViewManager
- DAP - DynamicAutomationPeer


| API | RN59 | RN60 | Current | vNext | Notes |
| :--- |  :----: | :-----: | :--------: | :-----: | :------ |
| **AccessibilityInfo Module** |  |  |  |  |  |
| isBoldTextEnabled() | N/A | iOS | No | N/A |  |
| isGrayscaleEnabled() | N/A | iOS | No | N/A |  |
| isInvertColorsEnabled() | N/A | iOS | No | N/A |  |
| isReduceMotionEnabled() | N/A | Both | No | #3110 |  |
| isReduceTransparencyEnabled() | N/A | iOS | No | N/A |  |
| isScreenReaderEnabled() | N/A | Both  | No | #3115 |  |
| addEventListener() | Both | Both  | Stub (JS) | #3159  | Implemented in JS code, not sure if it works |
| setAccessibilityFocus() | Both | Both  | No | #3116 |  |
| announceForAccessibility() | iOS | Both  | No | #3117 |  |
| removeEventListener() | Both | Both  | Stub (JS) | #3158  | Implemented in JS code, not sure if it works |
| fetch() | Both | N/A | Stub (JS) | #3157  | Hardcoded false, replaced by isScreenReaderEnabled() |
| **View Props** |  |  |  |  |  |
| accessible | Both | Both | No | Yes  | Via FEVM |
| accessibilityElementsHidden | iOS | iOS | No | N/A  |  |
| accessibilityHint | Both | Both | No | Yes | Via FEVM | 
| accessibilityIgnoresInvertColors | iOS | iOS | No | N/A | Investigate RN high-contrast vs. inversion story | 
| accessibilityLabel | Both | Both | Yes | Yes | Via FEVM | 
| accessibilityLiveRegion | Android | Android | Yes | Yes | Via FEVM |
| accessibilityRole | Both | Both | No | Yes | Up-to-date with RN60, via FEVM |
| accessibilityStates | Both | Both | No | Yes | Up-to-date with RN60, via FEVM |
| accessibilityViewIsModal | iOS | iOS | No | #3118 |  |
| importantForAccessibility | Android | Android | Yes | N/A |  |
| onAccessibilityEscape | iOS | iOS | No | #3119 |  | 
| onAccessibilityTap | iOS | iOS | No | #3120 | Via ViewViewManager, not shared with other components | 
| onMagicTap | iOS | iOS | No | #3121|  | 
| accessibilityActions | N/A | Both | No | #3122 |  | 
| onAccessibilityAction | N/A | Both | No | #3123 |  | 
| accessibilityTraits | iOS | N/A | Partial | N/A | Deprecated in RN60 | 
| accessibilityComponentType | Android | N/A | No | N/A | Deprecated in RN60 | 
| **Button Props** |  |  |  |  |  |
| accessibilityLabel | Both | Both | Yes | Yes | Via TouchableHighlight -> View Props -> FEVM |
| **Image Props** |  |  |  |  |  |
| accessible | Both | Both | No | Yes | Via FEVM |
| accessibilityLabel | Both | Both | Yes | Yes | Via FEVM |
| **Text Props** |  |  |  |  |  |
| accessible | Both | Both | No | Yes | Via FEVM | 
| accessibilityHint  | Both | Both | No | Yes | Via FEVM |
| accessibilityLabel | Both | Both | Yes | Yes | Via FEVM |
| accessibilityRole | N/A | Both | No | #3111 | Via FEVM, but requires DAP |
| accessibilityState | N/A | Both | No | #3111 | Via FEVM, but requires DAP |
| **TouchableWithoutFeedback Props** |  |  |  |  |  |
| accessible | Both | Both | No | Yes* | Works on FEVM-based component child |
| accessibilityHint | Both | Both | No | Yes* | Works on FEVM-based component child |
| accessibilityIgnoresInvertColors | N/A | iOS | No | #3160 | In JS type definition, never consumed by native code |
| accessibilityLabel | Both | Both | Yes | Yes* | Works on FEVM-based component child |
| accessibilityRole | Both | Both | No | #3111 | Works with View child only (via FEVM, but requires DAP) |
| accessibilityStates | Both | Both | No | #3111 | Works with View child only (via FEVM, but requires DAP) |
| accessibilityTraits | iOS | N/A | No | #3161 | In JS type definition, never consumed by native code, don't add | 
| accessibilityComponentType | Android | N/A | No | #3162 | In JS type definition, never consumed by native code, don't add | 

## Open Accessibility Topics
- ARIA Alignment
- Invoking story
- "Testing Narrator Support (Windows)" section needs added [here](https://facebook.github.io/react-native/docs/accessibility.html)
- Windows API extensions
- Some things in accessibility are tied explicitly to the view components that we do not have a good story for - setting these properties will not doing anything for the Windows UIA tools

body:
Split out from #2111
https://facebook.github.io/react-native/docs/image#blurradius

Not directly supported by Image element. Would need to drop down the Composition for this. One possible proposal (using RS2 APIs):
-Create a XamlCompositionBrushBbase and use this to fill the background of a Panel (eg Canvas)
-The XCBB would create a Composition EffectBrush for the blur, and a LoadedImageSurface as the input.

Use GaussianBlurEffect and CompositionEffectBrush in ReactImage

title: runWindows deploy is too fragile and specific. Can't find path.

milestone.title: MVP+ (vNext M5)
milestone.description:
After completing a MVP and moving vNext as the default template, this milestone covers work to fill out as much functionality as possible without requiring [WinUI 3](https://github.com/microsoft/microsoft-ui-xaml/blob/master/docs/roadmap.md#winui-3). Thus it will not achieve 100% core parity, but will increase completion.

Items of note:
- Match lean core (moving components out to extensions)
- Turbo Module support

body:
Part 1: The path is too fragile

Currently C# and C++ UWP apps build slightly different paths.  And the current mechanism in deployToWindows is quite fragile and too specific

```return glob.sync(`windows/*/AppPackages/*_${options.arch}_${configuration}_*`)[0];```
https://github.com/microsoft/react-native-windows/blob/48a23b5181c7e91c1ec243c9556a6e81351a8927/vnext/local-cli/runWindows/utils/deploy.js#L21

Should be changed to this instead ```return glob.sync(`windows/**/AppPackages/*_${options.arch}_${configuration}_*`)[0];``` 
Note the * to ** after windows/
So that it can better capture different paths. In my particular case the default path is
`\windows\target\x64\Debug\UwpAppName\UwpAppName\AppPackages\UwpAppName_1.0.0.0_x64_Debug_Test`

part 2.
Also looking for the AppxManifest.xml 
https://github.com/microsoft/react-native-windows/blob/48a23b5181c7e91c1ec243c9556a6e81351a8927/vnext/local-cli/runWindows/utils/deploy.js#L34

In the C++ UWP this generates to
``` `windows/target/${options.arch}/${configuration}/appName/AppName/AppxManifest.xml`) ```
So this would work.  ``` const appxPath = glob.sync(path.join(options.root, `windows/*/${options.arch}/${configuration}/**/AppxManifest.xml`))[0]; ```




part 3.
Although it does properly rely on Add-AppDevPackage instead of *.appx now. It then falls back onto a WindowsStoreAppUtils.ps1
https://github.com/microsoft/react-native-windows/blob/48a23b5181c7e91c1ec243c9556a6e81351a8927/vnext/local-cli/runWindows/utils/WindowsStoreAppUtils.ps1#L94

Which is out dated and only supports appx and appxbundle. 
But comparing it against the Add-AppDevPackage which supports appx, msix (the new format), appxbundle, msixbundle, among others. 

To be honest, a lot of the functionality of WindowsStoreAppUtils, shouldn't even be needed anymore since Add-AppDevPackage should be handling most of the stuff here now. 



At the time of this post, I was still using "react-native-windows": "0.59.0-vnext.32", but it doesn't appear to be resolved as of July 2, 2019.

title: New template project doesn't reference PropertySheets properly (C++)

milestone.title: MVP+ (vNext M5)
milestone.description:
After completing a MVP and moving vNext as the default template, this milestone covers work to fill out as much functionality as possible without requiring [WinUI 3](https://github.com/microsoft/microsoft-ui-xaml/blob/master/docs/roadmap.md#winui-3). Thus it will not achieve 100% core parity, but will increase completion.

Items of note:
- Match lean core (moving components out to extensions)
- Turbo Module support

body:
Looks like VisualStudio is considering the root to be \testProject\windows\
and looking here \testProject\windows\PropertySheets\x64.props
but they exist in \testProject\node_modules\react-native-windows\PropertySheets\x64.props


repro steps
```
> npm install -g react-native-cli
> react-native init testProject --version 0.60.6
> cd testProject
> yarn add rnpm-plugin-windows
> react-native windows --template vnext
```

and inside my (testProject/windows/testProject.sln) 
this is where they were added and seemingly have the wrong paths? 
```
Project("{2150E333-8FDC-42A3-9474-1A3956D46DE8}") = "PropertySheets", "PropertySheets", "{6F24927E-EE45-4DB2-91DA-DCC6E98B0C42}"
    ProjectSection(SolutionItems) = preProject
        PropertySheets\ARM.props = PropertySheets\ARM.props
        PropertySheets\Debug.props = PropertySheets\Debug.props
        PropertySheets\React.Cpp.props = PropertySheets\React.Cpp.props
        PropertySheets\Release.props = PropertySheets\Release.props
        PropertySheets\Warnings.props = PropertySheets\Warnings.props
        PropertySheets\Win32.props = PropertySheets\Win32.props
        PropertySheets\x64.props = PropertySheets\x64.props
        PropertySheets\x86.props = PropertySheets\x86.props
    EndProjectSection
EndProject
```


Either these files need to be copied to project root, or the paths of where to find them need to be updated.

Presumably, if user is expected to edit/add to these at all, they should be copied, since nothing in node_moduels gets checked into project's git.

title: StringToFacadeType missing "progress"

milestone.title: MVP+ (vNext M5)
milestone.description:
After completing a MVP and moving vNext as the default template, this milestone covers work to fill out as much functionality as possible without requiring [WinUI 3](https://github.com/microsoft/microsoft-ui-xaml/blob/master/docs/roadmap.md#winui-3). Thus it will not achieve 100% core parity, but will increase completion.

Items of note:
- Match lean core (moving components out to extensions)
- Turbo Module support

body:
https://github.com/microsoft/react-native-windows/blob/b7b40b934e7d935166ee827d66ac4f5b469add9b/vnext/ReactUWP/Modules/Animated/FacadeType.h#L41

I hit this assert, when my string was "progress"



```

React.UWP.dll!StringToFacadeType(const std::basic_string<char,std::char_traits<char>,std::allocator<char> > & string) Line 41
	at <snipped>\node_modules\react-native-windows\reactuwp\modules\animated\facadetype.h(41)
React.UWP.dll!react::uwp::PropsAnimatedNode::UpdateView() Line 79
	at <snipped>\node_modules\react-native-windows\reactuwp\modules\animated\propsanimatednode.cpp(79)
React.UWP.dll!react::uwp::PropsAnimatedNode::ConnectToView(__int64 viewTag) Line 35
	at <snipped>\node_modules\react-native-windows\reactuwp\modules\animated\propsanimatednode.cpp(35)
React.UWP.dll!react::uwp::NativeAnimatedNodeManager::ConnectAnimatedNodeToView(__int64 propsNodeTag, __int64 viewTag) Line 118
	at <snipped>\node_modules\react-native-windows\reactuwp\modules\animated\nativeanimatednodemanager.cpp(118)
React.UWP.dll!react::uwp::NativeAnimatedModule::ConnectAnimatedNodeToView(__int64 animatedNodeTag, __int64 viewTag) Line 168
	at <snipped>\node_modules\react-native-windows\reactuwp\modules\animated\nativeanimatedmodule.cpp(168)
React.UWP.dll!react::uwp::NativeAnimatedModule::getMethods::__l2::<lambda>(folly::dynamic args) Line 65
	at <snipped>\node_modules\react-native-windows\reactuwp\modules\animated\nativeanimatedmodule.cpp(65)

```

title: RNW CLI assumes App.windows.js entry point, ignoring existing code

milestone.title: MVP+ (vNext M5)
milestone.description:
After completing a MVP and moving vNext as the default template, this milestone covers work to fill out as much functionality as possible without requiring [WinUI 3](https://github.com/microsoft/microsoft-ui-xaml/blob/master/docs/roadmap.md#winui-3). Thus it will not achieve 100% core parity, but will increase completion.

Items of note:
- Match lean core (moving components out to extensions)
- Turbo Module support

body:
### Environment

1. `react-native -v`:

```
react-native-cli: 2.0.1
react-native: 0.59.8
```

2. `npm ls rnpm-plugin-windows`:

```
`-- rnpm-plugin-windows@0.2.11
```

3. `npm ls react-native-windows`:

```
`-- react-native-windows@0.59.0-vnext.95
```
4. `node -v`:

```
v10.15.3
```

5. `npm -v`:

```
6.10.1
```

Then, specify:

- Target Platform Version(s): 10.0.18362

- Target Device(s): Desktop

- Visual Studio Version: 2017

- Build Configuration: Debug

### Steps to Reproduce

I reprored with when using the `expo-cli` but it should be a problem with any existing app. I want add a RNW vnext target using `rnpm-plugin-windows`.

1. `expo eject`
2. Select "plain" RN project
3. As per #2808 , I add the missing `"name"` entry
4. `react-native windows --template vnext`
5. `react-native run-windows`

### Expected Behavior

The new project builds and launches my existing app. It should be smart enough to identify (and refer) any existing entry point:

* The "main" key in package.json
* The "entryPoint" key in app.json

### Actual Behavior

The generated project both creates an App.windows.js and hardcodes the entry-point to it in the native code.

title: Safer focus lost behavior

labels.name: Deliverable
labels.description: Major item tracked for top-level planning in ADO

milestone.title: MVP+ (vNext M5)
milestone.description:
After completing a MVP and moving vNext as the default template, this milestone covers work to fill out as much functionality as possible without requiring [WinUI 3](https://github.com/microsoft/microsoft-ui-xaml/blob/master/docs/roadmap.md#winui-3). Thus it will not achieve 100% core parity, but will increase completion.

Items of note:
- Match lean core (moving components out to extensions)
- Turbo Module support

body:
# Proposal: Safer focus lost behavior

## Summary
In Xaml, when the focused control is removed from the visual tree, focus moves to the first element in the window.  This differs from other platforms (I don't know how each works, but Xaml seems uniquely extreme in this) - I believe most platforms will find the nearest focusable element or at least keep focus in the same 'window' if focus was in a flyout or subwindow.

## Motivation

We have had multiple bugs in our current usage of RNW where a render() update removes the focused element.  We've had to add code outside of RNW to notice when this is happening and restore focus back into the RNW control.

vnext's 'safe harbor' feature which when calling blur() will move focus to the root of the reactcontrol is perhaps part of a solution - if it also worked to safe harbor within the nearest 'window' and not just the root.  Requiring the call to blur() is also a problem though if its not needed on other platforms.  react-native developers on other platforms are unlikely to be aware of this Xaml behavior and some kind of 'auto-blur' behavior on removal seems desirable.

## Basic example

Have a RN layout where a Touchable's onPress will re-render and create a different tree with different buttons.  Focus will jump to the root of the window.  If doing this in a flyout, focus jumps all the way to parent window root.

## Open Questions

I attempted to start implementing this just using the current safe harbor, by checking if the current view being removed is the focused element.
1. That wouldn't solve the sub-window case
2. When re-rendering a tree of elements, the elements much higher in the tree are going to be removed first.  So instead of checking if the view being removed is focused, I had to check if the focused element is a child of the view being removed.  I wasn't sure of an efficient check for this and ended up having to walk all the parents up to the root from the focused element seeing it one of them was the element being removed. 
3. On RS4+ Platforms OnLosingFocus() could maybe be used to help with this.  Thats what we did with our LivePersonaCard feature, but it didn't work on RS3 due to unavailable APIs.  The app there notices focus movement and closes flyouts automatically on focus lost - fixing focus quickly isn't enough since nothing is async in the flyout manager.

body:
[PR 4369](https://github.com/webdriverio/webdriverio/pull/4369) described the problem between WinAppDriver and WebDriverIO.
I always created PR on WinAppDriver to fix the problem, but still no ETA to release it.
Possible adopt the newest WinAppDriver or use forked WebDriverIO.

title: Add FontFamily registration system
Align AppTheme API with Lean Core Appearance API

milestone.title: MVP (vNext M4)
milestone.description:
This "MVP" milestone tracks implementation of as much of RN core without significant workarounds current XAML (which would require [WinUI 3](https://github.com/microsoft/microsoft-ui-xaml/blob/master/docs/roadmap.md#winui-3)).

- vNext is the default template (with vCurrent available as a fallback for compat for existing apps)
- Native Modules ready to be developed
- Measured percentage of lean core API completion (specific target percentage TBD)
- Built on [WinUI 2.x](https://github.com/microsoft/microsoft-ui-xaml/)

body:
# Align AppTheme API with Lean Core Appearance API
We have a Windows-only API module called AppTheme. Which enables you to listen to the dark and light theme state changes for Windows.

As of [this commit](https://github.com/facebook/react-native/commit/63fa3f21c5ab308def450bffb22054241a8842ef), React Native core has an iOS and Android ones. It operates very similarly to how ours does, but there are some API name changes.

This proposal is to align the names with the Lean Core implementation, so that we can push up the Windows theme changed event work up to React Native to sit along side the iOS and Android implementations.

## Summary
<!-- Brief explanation of the new API or change. -->
We must make sure our Windows implementation of the theme changed event maps to the React Native `Appearance ` and the `getColorScheme()` function, instead of `AppTheme` and the `currentTheme` string property.

We should also separately PR the highContrastedChanged work into the `Appearance` API to enable support for that type of theme change.

## Motivation
In order for our Windows implementation of theme changed events to work properly in React Native's lean core, we must align with their implementation of theme changed events.

> This Windows alignment is happening on the JS-layer only.

The JS API to align with can be found in the [Libraries/Utilities/Appearance.js](https://github.com/facebook/react-native/blob/master/Libraries/Utilities/Appearance.js) file on the React Native repo.

## Basic example

<!-- [Optional] If the proposal involves a new or changed API, include a basic code example. Omit this section if it's not applicable. -->

``` javascript
import { Appearance } from 'react-native'

  render() {
    return (
      <Button title='click me' color={Appearance.getColorScheme() === 'dark' ? 'grey' : 'orange'}></Button>
    );
  }
```

## Contributing Back

As mentioned above, it's important that during this alignment that we do not lose the `highContrastedChanged` implemented within AppTheme. This is an important feature for windows users and something we should contribute back to React Native core with.

title: Add Windows support to expo's native directory (and expand other metadata about reliability)

milestone.title: MVP+ (vNext M5)
milestone.description:
After completing a MVP and moving vNext as the default template, this milestone covers work to fill out as much functionality as possible without requiring [WinUI 3](https://github.com/microsoft/microsoft-ui-xaml/blob/master/docs/roadmap.md#winui-3). Thus it will not achieve 100% core parity, but will increase completion.

Items of note:
- Match lean core (moving components out to extensions)
- Turbo Module support

body:
# Proposal: Add Windows support to expo's native directory (and expand other metadata about reliability)

## Summary

There's an existing directory of React Native modules here: https://www.native.directory/
It doesn't list Windows support. And it'd be nice if it factored in some other details like CI level. The directory is open source, so we could contribute back to it. Or, if we feel like there's a better direction for React Native module discovery then we could propose a new solution.

## Motivation

Help developers discover React Native community modules that meet their needs

## Resources

Logic for calculating the score:
https://github.com/react-native-community/react-native-directory/blob/master/scripts/calculate-score.js
Metadata for specific libraries:
https://github.com/react-native-community/react-native-directory/blob/master/react-native-libraries.json
    
Some other plugin directories:
https://pub.dev/flutter
https://www.gatsbyjs.org/plugins/

title: windowsbrush cannot be used in TypeScript

milestone.title: MVP+ (vNext M5)
milestone.description:
After completing a MVP and moving vNext as the default template, this milestone covers work to fill out as much functionality as possible without requiring [WinUI 3](https://github.com/microsoft/microsoft-ui-xaml/blob/master/docs/roadmap.md#winui-3). Thus it will not achieve 100% core parity, but will increase completion.

Items of note:
- Match lean core (moving components out to extensions)
- Turbo Module support

body:
If you try to use a windowsbrush in a TypeScript app file, this generates a TypeScript compiler error.

For example this jsx:
        <Button
          title="Sample Button"
          color={{windowsbrush: 'SystemAccentColorLight3'}}
          onPress={this._onPress}
        />
generates this compiler error:
23           color={{windowsbrush: 'SystemAccentColorLight3'}}
  ../node_modules/@types/react-native/index.d.ts:6916:5
    6916     color?: string;
The expected type comes from property 'color' which is declared here on type 'IntrinsicAttributes & IntrinsicClassAttributes<Button> & Readonly<ButtonProps> & Readonly<{ children?: ReactNode; }>'

I believe this is another instance where DefinitelyTyped changes would be needed:
https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/tree/master/types/react-native

For now apps can work-around the issue by adding // @ts-ignore but this is not ideal.

title: Picker does not have rounded corners when "borderRadius" style is used
body:
### Environment

<!--
  Please fill in all the relevant fields by running these commands in terminal.
-->
1. `react-native -v`:
react-native-cli: 2.0.1
react-native: 0.60.6
2. `npm ls rnpm-plugin-windows`:
rnpm-plugin-windows@0.3.5
3. `npm ls react-native-windows`:
react-native-windows@0.60.0-vnext.39
4. `node -v`:
v10.15.0
5. `npm -v`:
6.13.1

Then, specify:

<!-- (What SDK version are you building for? Choose from 10.0.15063, 10.0.16299, 10.0.18362, etc. -->
- Target Platform Version(s): 10.0.18362.0

<!-- (What device(s) are you targeting? Choose any from Desktop, Xbox, Hololens) -->
- Target Device(s): Desktop

<!-- Which version of Visual Studio are you using? Specify Visual Studio 2017 or Visual Studio 2019 -->
- Visual Studio Version: 2017

<!-- Which build configuration are you running? Choose from Debug, DebugBundle, Release, ReleaseBundle -->
- Build Configuration: Debug

### Steps to Reproduce

<!--
  How would you describe your issue to someone who doesn’t know you or your project?
  Try to write a sequence of steps that anybody can repeat to see the issue.
  Be specific! If the bug cannot be reproduced, your issue may be closed.
-->

1. Create a Picker in a project using React Native Windows
2. Apply a style containing "borderRadius"
3. Observe that the Picker does not have rounded corners

Example code:

```
import { Picker, StyleSheet } from "react-native";

const styleSheet = StyleSheet.create({
    roundedCorners: {
        borderRadius: 3,
    },
});

render() {
    return (
          <Picker style={styleSheet.roundedCorners}>
                <Picker.Item label="Any" value="Any" />
          </Picker>
     );
}
```

### Expected Behavior

<!--
  How did you expect your project to behave?
  It’s fine if you’re not sure your understanding is correct.
  Just write down what you thought would happen.
-->

I expected the Picker to have rounded corners using the supplied border radius.

### Actual Behavior

<!--
  Did something go wrong?
  Is something broken, or not behaving as you expected?
  Describe this section in detail, and attach screenshots if possible.
  Don't just say "it doesn't work"!
-->

Applying the "borderRadius" style did not visually change the box. It still has rounded corners.

Screenshot:
![snip1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/58611963/71039598-60aa7f80-20d9-11ea-9817-75d6fe2d6e66.png)
